data.title: “The Use of Knowledge in Society” (1945)
data.meta_description: One of Hayek’s most important contributions to economic theory is his demonstration of the part prices play in disseminating widely diffused knowledge about consumer demand and the availablility of economic resources in order to make rational economic calculation possible.
data.text:
The impetus of Hayek’s essay was to respond to Lange’s work on centrally planned economies. In this work, Lange defends his form of “market socialism.”

Cockshott and Cottrell wrote their academic paper as a direct response to Hayek’s criticisms of central planning, and the broader critique of socialist economies which stemmed from The Use of Knowledge in Society. In a life that spanned almost the entire twentieth century, Hayek went from being dismissed, ridiculed, and ignored to being recognized and acclaimed as perhaps this century’s most significant social scientist and philosopher. To a remarkable degree, his story is the story of the twentieth century.…

Hayek included The Use of Knowledge in Society essay in this collection of 12 essays discussing many of his ideas on philosophy and economics.

Boudreaux and Russ Roberts discuss the importance of Hayek’s work, and how to go about reading one of the most influential economic thinkers of the twentieth century.
